column1: Canelones (Spanish pronunciation: [kaneˈlones]) is the capital of the department of Canelones in Uruguay. Its name is derived from a species of cinnamon
column3: growing along the banks of the homonymous river. Since 2010
column4: the city is also the seat of the municipality of Canelones.

column1: The city is located on Route 5 about 50 kilometres (31 mi) North of Montevideo and on its intersection with Route 64. It lies on the west bank of the river Arroyo Canelón Chico.
It was founded on 24 April 1783 under the name "Villa Guadalupe". It became capital of one of the nine earlier Departments of the Republic. The railroad arrived here in 1874
column2: while in 1908 National Route 5 from Montevideo was inaugurated. On 23 March 1916
column3: it was renamed to "Canelones" and its status was elevated to "Ciudad" (city) by the Act of Ley Nº 5.400.

column4: the Intendencia de Canelones had recorded a population of 25
column5: 961 for the municipality during the elections. While Canelones is the capital of the department of the same name
column6: it has a considerably smaller population compared with two other cities in the department
column7: Ciudad de la Costa and Las Piedras.

column1: Source: Instituto Nacional de Estadística de Uruguay
The city and the department have numerous small to large vineyards and wineries. In 1987 the cold-storage facility "Frigorífico Canelones" was founded
column2: which ever since became the principal industry of the city.
